Navigation
Name Rascal/Libraries/Prelude/ParseTree/parseWithErrorTree
Synopsis Parse input text (from a string or a location) and return a parse tree which can contain error nodes.
Function
  1. &T<:Tree parseWithErrorTree(type[&T<:Tree] begin, str input)
  2. &T<:Tree parseWithErrorTree(type[&T<:Tree] begin, str input, loc origin)
  3. &T<:Tree parseWithErrorTree(type[&T<:Tree] begin, loc input)
Usage import ParseTree;
Description
  1. Parse a string and return a parse tree.
  2. Parse a string and return a parse tree, origin defines the original location of the input.
  3. Parse the contents of resource input and return a parse tree.
In all the above cases, the parse tree may contain error nodes.
Examples 
rascal>import demo::lang::Exp::Concrete::NoLayout::Syntax;
ok
rascal>import ParseTree;
ok
First, parse an incorrect expression and get an error message: 
rascal>parse(#Exp, "2+");
Uncaught Rascal Exception: prompt:///:1,12: ParseError(|file://-|(2,0,<1,2>,<1,2>))
    /:1,12
    somewhere in: $shell$
    somewhere in: public org.eclipse.imp.pdb.facts.IValue org.rascalmpl.library.Prelude.parse(org.eclipse.imp.»
pdb.facts.IValue,org.eclipse.imp.pdb.facts.IString,org.rascalmpl.interpreter.IEvaluatorContext)
    somewhere in: $shell$
Next, parse an incorrect expression and get an error tree: 
rascal>parseWithErrorTree(#Exp, "2+");
Uncaught Rascal Exception: prompt:///:1,25: Java("Parse error")
